bibl.title: Letter from Bessie C. Wratten to Emilie Lawrence Reed, March 27, 1912

div1.p: Wratten informs Emilie Lawrence Reed that her husband will offer assistance with her writing.

div1.head: Letter from Bessie C. Wratten to Emilie Lawrence Reed, March 27, 1912
div1.p:
Your note to
Mr. Wratten was received by
me, yesterday. He is at Kansas
City Mo. in the hospital.
Has been there nearly 6 months.
I hope to have him home 'ere
another two months have
passed. He has had a terrible
siege for the past 3 years, Drs.
give me encouragement, though.
They say he will get up and
walk again, though will
never be strong. Will always
be a cripple. I don't suppose you
will remember me, Mrs. Reed - though
I remember going to Sunday School
to Miss Lee (I believe she was your
governess)- also, remember Lawrence
& Blossom- I didn't see him when
he was here - was on a visit to
my home, Mt. Vernon, Ala. Please
tell me of Blossom. If she is
married, has a family, etc. My
mother, Mrs. B. A. Cannon, is very
devoted to Dr. Reed's memory. She
feels that he saved her life, once,
and always talks of him as having been being
the best, grandest physician on earth.
We have five little ones. I married
Mr. Wratten in 1899- Am sending
your note to him, this morning and
am sure he will, gladly do all he
can, to help you with your story.
May we hope for a copy when you
have it published? Pardon me
for having written, but I could not
resist the temptation to ask about
Blossom. We remember her as such a
sweet little girl.

May I hear from you, if
only a post card?
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Bessie Cannon Wratten. Address of
Mr. Geo. M. Wratten,
St. Joseph's Hospital,
Kansas City,
Mo.
Room 219
Hugh L. Scott
Col. 3rd Cav
Fort Sam Houston
Texas
